title: What is the Approach of Anthroposophy towards Martinism and the Question of Tradition in the West?
first_phrase: In the previous text, the author contests the idea of Jesus being the central figure of initiation, history and the universe in the Western esoteric tradition. The last part of the text explores how anthroposophy, a spiritual movement founded by Rudolf Steiner, has approached Martinism, a Christian esoteric tradition. The author notes that while Martinists and anthroposophists share some beliefs, they disagree on the central role of Jesus. The text discusses the meaning and dividing line between East and West, and argues that Rome is the center of the West due to its historical and cultural influence.

last_phrase: In conclusion, defining the boundaries between East and West solely based on geography is inadequate. Considering the historical and cultural influence of Rome, it would be more practical to perceive Rome as the center of the West while Asia, excluding Egypt, as the East. Thus, the line of separation could be drawn from the pyramid of Cheope, including the Hellenized coasts of Anatolia in the West.
